Based on my conversations with some people about the "10 years you were 'me now'" business the main confusion seems to be that it sounds like identification with an entity who lives across time because you refer to the person from 10 years ago and the person right now as both "me now." However the actual essence of what is trying to be communicated by the phrase is the exact opposite, that you have no experience of duration because you only experience now, and no personal connection to anything in the past or future at all. 

Maybe a better version but maybe a much more convoluted version of the phrase is "10 years ago a person experienced who is not you but who you think you are experienced 'me now.' Right now you experience 'me now.' Right *now* you experience 'me now' and you are a different person since the last time I said that. 10 years from now there will be a person who will experience 'me now' but that person is also not you." 

And at some point include the alien analogy to explain why the past person is not you.

Ask yourself what your direct perception of time actually is. If the continuity of time changed would it affect your experience at all? If the universe skipped a day would you notice? If the past never actually happened would it affect you? Do you experience time at all?

Your reasoning with the apple analogy seems correct. 

I think the difference between an apple and yourself is that the apple is something that can actually be observed with your 5 main senses, whereas there is no actual direct experience of a "me". "Me" is entirely a construct that only exists in thought. The construct is a result of believing there to be a continuity of experiencing "my life", when there isn't actually any continuity at all. 

As for advice, usually I tell everyone to meditate on time. That's what I found most helpful. 
Inquiring into emotions can also clarify what you really believe. If your thoughts conflict with your emotions, the emotions are what you believe and the thoughts are you trying to lie to yourself. I think it's also important to understand that believing there to be a "me" who can acquire SR *is itself* a result of the self-image. SR is not a process of becoming. It's a realization of what there is right now. The SR realization occurred to me a few days after I gave up on trying to actively do self-inquiry. I bet that's not a coincidence. 
Tldr: my advice is to inquire into time, inquire into emotions, and remember that acquiring SR isn't possible

The key misunderstanding is in the perception of time. The self-image is a collection of memories believed to be about your past. To be able to think about yourself, you would have to be able to think about the past. However, when you recall a memory, that is a sensory perception occurring *right now* with no real relationship with the past. Another way of thinking of it is that you can't actually prove the past happened, which means you have no direct experience of it. Thoughts about the past are still thoughts that occur "now". 

The realization results from a direct insight into your perception of time and thought, not from logical reasoning. SR is not an intellectual belief so the understanding cannot come from reason alone. 

In Jamie's his original walkthrough essay he described the "So am I, so that can't be you" game, which demonstrates that any attempt to understand yourself intellectually can never be what you really are, because it could also apply to someone else. That is a good starting point for tearing down the intellectual answer to the question "who am I". 

My personal recommendation is always just to tell everyone to inquire into their perception of time, because that is *the crux* of the phenomenon. Without understanding time, none of this makes sense .
